speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] Well, I'd like to take this opportunity to wish you The very, very best of holidays.  Like many of you, I'll be spending the time in the loving embrace of my family - which should give us all plenty to talk about in the new year. Meanwhile, this is Dr. Frasier Crane, KACL 780, Talk Radio.

speaker: Roz
text: Come on, Frasier.  There's a gin-and-tonic out there with my name on it.

speaker: Bulldog
text: You can tell Father Mike's had a few.  He's trying to get everyone to re-enact the Nativity scene.

speaker: Roz
text: [_to Bulldog, as she exits_] Well, we know who we could get to be the ass.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_gives a dog growl, then to Frasier_] I'm wearing her down.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Who's that for?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's for Roz.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_reading the box_] "Amazing trick microphone, squirts water." Nice.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a gag.  We agreed not to exchange gifts.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Listen doc.  I'm scheduled to do the noon-to-four on Christmas.

speaker: Frasier
text: No.

speaker: Bulldog
text: But doc, my whole family's getting together in Chicago for the first time in five years.

speaker: Frasier
text: I am touched, and I don't care.

speaker: Bulldog
text: But my-my-my sister and her new baby...

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen Bulldog, my son Frederick is flying in tomorrow afternoon to spend the holidays with me.  Now, I've never looked so forward to a Christmas since I was... well, your size.

speaker: Dave
text: DID YOU TELL HIM YET, BULLDOG?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Okay, you don't have to yell.  You're not in the chopper giving us a traffic report.

speaker: Dave
text: I WAS YELLING?

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_gives up_] Hey, doc.  You know, ah, Bonnie Weems, right?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, ah, I don't actually know her, but she does the auto show, right?

speaker: Dave
text: RIGHT.  Bonnie tends to drink a little more than she should at these parties, so the newest on-air personality always drives her home!

speaker: Bulldog
text: That's you, rookie.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that sounds like a good tradition, I'd be delighted to drive her home.

speaker: Bulldog
text: And she'll be delighted to hear that. _Bulldog and Dave exit, giggling.  Frasier follows them into the corridor and helps himself to a glass of punch.  Elizabeth, an elderly employee, comes up to him._

speaker: Elizabeth
text: Merry Christmas, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Merry Christmas, Elizabeth.

speaker: Elizabeth
text: I baked you some sugar cookies. [_hands over box_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, how sweet of you.  Sweets from the sweet.

speaker: Elizabeth
text: Would you by any chance know who's driving Bonnie Weems home tonight?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I am.  And maybe you can tell me why everyone...

speaker: Elizabeth
text: [_to crowd_] Hey, everybody!  It's the doc! _The entire party starts laughing.  Confused, Frasier goes back into the booth.  Roz is there._

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, would you mind telling me why everyone breaks into hysterics whenever I say I'm driving Bonnie Weems home... [_Roz bursts out laughing_] Oh, what is that?!

speaker: Roz
text: Well, Bonnie Weems is kind of an office legend.  She gets a couple of drinks under her belt, and she gets a little amorous. And she will not take "No" for an answer.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is that all?  Oh, I'm a big boy, I can take care of myself.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_picking up present_] Now, listen Roz, Roz, now I know we promised not to, but I couldn't help it.  I was out shopping, and...

speaker: Roz
text: [_really excited_] Oh, no!  Don't worry, Frasier, I couldn't help myself either.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, really?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes. [_hands over gift_] Merry Christmas!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Roz, you shouldn't have.  This is just...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_worried_] Oh, Roz.  Roz, you _really_ shouldn't have.

speaker: Roz
text: Now it's my turn. [_starts opening her gift_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no-no-no.  Maybe, you know, maybe you should just think about, ah... keeping it under the tree.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, me wait to open a Christmas present?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah.

speaker: Roz
text: [_opens box, but manages to fake enthusiasm for the gag gift_] Oh my god!  It's great!  It's great because I'm in radio!

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, that's what I was going for, yes.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, thanks a million, Frasier. [_kisses him_] Have a happy, happy holiday and I'll see you next week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay.  Merry Christmas.

speaker: Roz
text: Merry Christmas. _She leaves.  Bonnie Weems, a very attractive blond, appears in the doorway with a drink in her hand._

speaker: Bonnie
text: Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes?

speaker: Bonnie
text: I'm Bonnie Weems.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, hello.  It's a, uh, a pleasure to meet you.  I'll be driving you home tonight.

speaker: Bonnie
text: I'm sorry to put you out.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, it's no problem at all.  Tell you what, you just go, enjoy the party, you let me know when you're ready to go.

speaker: Bonnie
text: [_downs her shot in one_] I'm ready now, baby. _She lifts Frasier by the waist, puts him over her shoulder and carries him out.  Scene B: Frasier's Apartment. Niles is there, drinking eggnog.  He puts his glass down to clean a mark on his shoe.  Eddie immediately takes a few laps from it, sitting back down before Niles picks it up and takes a sip.  Frasier enters with a pile of presents.  Niles starts, looking like a kid caught with his hand in the cookie jar._

speaker: Niles
text: [_nervously_] Hello, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hello Niles.  Merry Christmas.  To what do I owe this occasion?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, nothing.  Just stopped by to get an opinion on a gift I was considering for Maris.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, it pinches a bit under the arms, but you be the judge. [_does a little twirl_] Oh, hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_glaring at Niles_] Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_to Niles_] Shall I put the little red one back on so you can Make your choice?

speaker: Frasier
text: I think Niles has all the information he needs, thank you.

speaker: Daphne
text: Fair enough.

speaker: Niles
text: You know, Maris and Daphne are roughly the same size!

speaker: Frasier
text: Give or take a foot.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Frasier.  Where've you been?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, after the Christmas party I poured a colleague into a cab, said a quick prayer for the driver, dislodged the wedgie of a lifetime, then went on to do a little bit of last minute shopping.  Niles, some sherry?

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Santa is going to be very, very good to Frederick This year.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, by the way, Bulldog called a couple of times.  He wanted to know if you'd take his slot on Christmas day.

speaker: Frasier
text: I already told him no.  How long will that man nag me? [_Martin heads towards the door with a cheap, plastic wreath_] Dad, what are you doing with that?

speaker: Martin
text: I'm gonna hang it on the front door, like I always do.

speaker: Frasier
text: But it's plastic.

speaker: Martin
text: [_hanging it_] Well, of course it's plastic.  Do you think a real one would've lasted since 1967? _As Frasier hands Niles a sherry, Daphne enters carrying the two cocktail dresses._

speaker: Daphne
text: Here you go.  Ooh, I'm glad to be out of that black one-- I had to take me undies off just to get the zipper up. _Niles drops his glass, shattering it on the table and spilling sherry all over it._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, dear!  Let me get that. _As she starts to clean up, Niles sinks onto the couch, still bringing himself together.  The phone rings.  Martin answers._

speaker: Martin
text: Hello.  Oh, hi. [_to Frasier_] Frasier, it's for you.  It's the nag.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, lord. [_on phone_] Now, listen Bulldog, I already told you... Oh.  Hello, Lilith.  Well, you know, maybe, ah, I should take this in the bedroom. [_exits_]

speaker: Martin
text: Niles?  Everything's all set for tomorrow, right?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, yes.  Maris and I are driving up to the cabin tonight. We'll expect you, Frasier and Frederick tomorrow around noon.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I wish I was coming with you.

speaker: Niles
text: So do I.

speaker: Martin
text: [_passing the phone, hearing Frasier and Lilith arguing_] Oh, Shut the hell up, will you? [_puts phone back on hook_]

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne.  Daphne, you should come.  We have the most wonderful traditional Christmas, it's an actual log cabin.  With actual deer grazing in the snow on our front yard.  Of course, Maris fires off her shotgun from time to time to scare them away from our garbage, but still, it's enchanting.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  You sure you can't come, Daph?

speaker: Daphne
text: No, I promised my Uncle Jackie I'd fly down to San Francisco to be with him.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I guess you should be with your family at this time of year, it's more traditional.

speaker: Daphne
text: Except that Jackie's a transvestite.  Getting a bit long in the tooth for it too, if you ask me.  Last Thanksgiving he ate too much turkey and I had to cut him out of his pantyhose.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Merry Christmas, everybody!  Lilith isn't sending Frederick!

speaker: Martin
text: What?  Why not?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, apparently he has this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for an incredible Christmas.  A friend of hers has rented a home in Austria.

speaker: Martin
text: What's the matter with the good old U.S.A.?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, apparently it's the same house that they filmed "The Sound Of Music" in, and that happens to be Freddie's favorite movie.  Well, Julie Andrews is singing with the Salzburg Choral, they're having dinner with her afterwards, and some nonsense about a horse-driven sleigh ride through the snow, and a toboggan, and a balloon trip through the Alps, and apparently on their way back they're gonna spend an entire day at Euro-Disneyland!

speaker: Niles
text: ...Well, up at the cabin, there's an old stump that the local children seem to enjoy kicking.

speaker: Martin
text: You know you have to let him go, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, of course I have to let him go.  Thank you for pointing out that you know what's right.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey!  I was just making sure that you did, that's all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, how would I ever live without you?

speaker: Daphne
text: Now now, boys, that's enough.  Dr. Crane, you're being a good father, letting Frederick go.

speaker: Niles
text: That's right.  It doesn't have to ruin your Christmas.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, come on.  Let's finish decorating the Christmas tree. I brought up the good lights from the storage room.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dad, you know what, I don't want to use those lights this year.  I picked up these just yesterday. [_brings out a box of lights_]

speaker: Martin
text: Chili peppers?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes, they're very fashionable.

speaker: Martin
text: Chili peppers aren't Christmas.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, for that matter, neither are scotch pines or snow ornaments.  For God's sakes, if you want to be technical, Bethlehem was in the desert.

speaker: Martin
text: Fine.  Why don't we decorate a palm tree?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't need your sarcasm.

speaker: Martin
text: But I always use those lights.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, dad.  This is my house, these are my decorations, just once, could I have just one thing I wanted this Christmas?

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, look.  Wait a minute.  I know you're upset about Freddie, but don't take it out on me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh fine.  Now you're the psychiatrist?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I give up.  Go ahead, decorate the thing.  Use your chili peppers!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, I won't anymore!

speaker: Martin
text: Use 'em!  Why don't... maybe we could hang a few radishes, put a nice broccoli on top!

speaker: Niles
text: I hope you two aren't going to be behaving this way up at the cabin?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, we won't!  Because I'm not going to the cabin!

speaker: Martin
text: What do you mean, you're not going to the cabin?  Where the hell are you going?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm staying right here.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you can't stay alone on Christmas. [_by this time, Eddie Has his head under a cushion_]

speaker: Frasier
text: I've decided to fill in for Bulldog!  At least somebody will have a Merry Christmas!

speaker: Martin
text: [_mad_] Well, Merry Christmas!

speaker: Frasier
text: MERRY CHRISTMAS!

speaker: Martin
text: MERRY CHRISTMAS!!

speaker: Frasier
text: MERRY CHRISTMAS!!! _Eddie pops his head out, decides it's still not safe, and sticks it back under the cushion._  _End of Act One  Act Two.  Scene A: Radio Station. Frasier walks down the hallway, unshaved and wearing an old sweatshirt and jeans. He is following Roz, who is much cleaner, but wearing a very large scowl._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz... I didn't realize when I volunteered to work on Christmas that I would ruin your plans for the day, I... please don't be mad. [_they enter the booth_]

speaker: Roz
text: Mad?  What for?  My mother just flew all the way in from Wisconsin to be here with me today.  But instead I'm back in this stinking hellhole on Christmas Day, when only the loneliest and most depressed people on the planet would EVER call in.  But, look how nice you made yourself look for me!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, try to see this thing from my position.  I, I couldn't see my son, I had a terrible fight with my father, I was facing a horrible Christmas, and then I thought, you know, maybe if by trying to help other people through their troubles it might get me through mine, and I think if we really try hard, we can maybe have the best Christmas we've ever had. What do you say?

speaker: Roz
text: Okay.  I'm not mad.  Get ready.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I need a hug, just to prove that we're still friends.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I am not hugging you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Come on.

speaker: Roz
text: No, you're grungy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Come to papa.

speaker: Roz
text: All right! [_hugs_] We're friends.  Now get ready, we're on.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] Merry Christmas, Seattle!  Yes, this is Dr. Frasier Crane coming to you on Christmas Day.  Christmas, that very magical time of the year, when each moment is as unique as a snowflake, never to be recreated.

speaker: Roz
text: I'm sorry Frasier, the news went over you.  You're gonna have to do that again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Merry Christmas, Seattle...! _DISSOLVE TO: Later  Time lapse.  Frasier and Roz are still on the air, both looking VERY depressed._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as we head into our second hour, I'd like to lighten things up a bit.  Although, Ned, we were certainly glad to hear from you, and how you got mugged on your way home from the soup kitchen.  Roz, who's next?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Don on line five, he wants to tell us about the time he was filled with the Christmas spirit.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's about time!  Hello, Don.

speaker: Don
text: [_v.o._] Hello, Dr. Crane.  Something happened the other day that sums up why we call this the season of giving.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well then, swaddle me in Christmas cheer.

speaker: Don
text: Okay.  Well, you see, I was driving home from the gym, and I suddenly realized I had left my favorite old pair of sneakers on the roof of the car.  So, I look back and there's this homeless guy, and he'd already picked them up, and he's putting 'em on.  So I just thought, what the hell, and kept on driving.

speaker: Frasier
text: So your experience of the Christmas spirit would be that you didn't slam the car into reverse, speed back there, and rip a pair of smelly old sneakers out of a homeless man's hand? Well Roz, this is special, I think we've got Santa Claus himself on the line! _DISSOLVE TO: Later  Time lapse.  Frasier is listening to Barry, a caller who can't stop crying long enough to say what his problem is._

speaker: Barry
text: [_v.o._] I'm sorry.  That was the last time.  I'm okay now, I'm okay. [_bursts into tears again_] No, I'm not!

speaker: Frasier
text: Barry, I've got to put you on hold for a bit, while you pull yourself together, but please, please stay on the line, I'd really like to help you.

speaker: Barry
text: It's alright, I think I've got a hold of myself... [_starts crying again_] _DISSOLVE TO: Later  Time lapse._

speaker: Gladys
text: [_v.o._] So you see, Dr. Crane, I've fallen in the shower so many times, they can't fit any more pins in my hip.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gladys, Gladys?  Ah, listen, can I put you on hold for a second?  There's somebody else I have to check on. [_switches lines_] How's it going there, Barry?

speaker: Frasier
text: My sentiments exactly. _DISSOLVE TO: Later  Time lapse.  By this time, Roz has her head on the desk, and Frasier is tilted back in his chair, the mike balanced on his chest._

speaker: Tom
text: [_v.o._] It still traumatizes me, Dr. Crane.  I wake up nights, and I remember that Christmas morning.  I walked into my mother's bedroom, tears running down my face, and I said, "Mommy... the puppy Santa gave me won't wake up."

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, Tom.  You win the prize for the saddest Christmas story we've heard today.  Happy holidays.  _He goes to a commercial break, sees Roz with her head down and rushes into her booth._

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz?  Roz!  Oh, have you been crying, Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: [_weeping_] Just for the last hour.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh... oh, listen, why don't you just go home, honey?  I can take over for the next two hours.

speaker: Roz
text: But you can't do this on your own.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, sure I can!  Why don't you go home, be with your mom?

speaker: Roz
text: Wouldn't it be even be sadder?  With you here all by yourself?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't think that's possible.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, if you really mean it, I'll go.

speaker: Frasier
text: I mean it.

speaker: Roz
text: But Frasier, promise me one thing?  Don't sit here and get more depressed.  You'll see your little boy again soon.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know I will.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay.  Hug-hug-hug? [_they hug_] Merry... [_bursts into tears again_] Christmas!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on-air_] Hi, we're back.  Well, you know what?  I, I realize it's been a pretty tough day out there for most of you, and uh, I'd like to hear now from someone who's having a GOOD Christmas.  Um, you know, someone who's learned a way to beat the holiday blues.  Well, let's take our first call here. [_presses button_] Hello, you're on the air.

speaker: Jeff
text: [_v.o._] This is Jeff.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Jeff!  Well, Merry Christmas!

speaker: Jeff
text: Well, Merry Christmas to you.  I used to get depressed on Christmas.  And then I found a surefire way to beat it: I'd pop my favorite movie, "The Sound Of Music" in the VCR. Watching Julie Andrews lead those adorable little tykes through the streets of Salzburg... Nobody could be depressed! I mean, nobody!

speaker: Frasier
text: Jeff, are you a betting man?  _DISSOLVE TO:  Time lapse.  Frasier is wrapping up._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we're just about out of time.  My, my, this day has flown by.  I'd like to wish all of you revelers out there a Merry Christmas, and for the rest of you, why don't you go out and treat yourself to something special?  Personally, I'm going to go get myself a meal at one of Seattle's fine eateries.  I don't know where, but I promise you one thing: it'll have a liquor license.  Just kidding.  Don't drink and drive.  This is Dr. Frasier Crane, KACL 780, Talk Radio.   **MIRACLE ON THIRD OR FOURTH STREET**  _Scene B: A Diner. Through the window we see Frasier park his car.  He gets out and enters, taking a seat at the counter._

speaker: Waitress
text: [_mechanically_] Merry Christmas.  Welcome to Lou's.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  I'm sure glad you're open, all the other places in town are either closed or are all booked up.

speaker: Waitress
text: That's what makes us so special.  I can bring you a menu, but almost everybody's having the Christmas platter.  That's a turkey log with mashed potatoes, then yule log for dessert.

speaker: Frasier
text: How much more appetizing food always becomes when you add the word "log." [_she stares at him_] I'll just have the Christmas platter.

speaker: Waitress
text: [_she yells_] PLATTER!

speaker: Tim
text: How you doin'?

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay.

speaker: Tim
text: Are you havin' a merry Christmas?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, now that you ask, no I'm not.  Can't be with my son, had a terrible argument over something stupid with my father. That's why I'm alone.  How about you?

speaker: Tim
text: Pretty good, actually.  Just yesterday, I was crossing the street, and this beautiful pair of sneakers flew off the back of the car, and landed on my feet! [_holds them up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Merry Christmas.

speaker: Waitress
text: [_bringing him his platter_] Here you go.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the chef didn't exactly dally over the Remoulade, did he?  _DISSOLVE TO:  Time lapse.  Frasier has almost finished his meal.  Tim is asleep on his shoulder. A man (Bill) enters._

speaker: Bill
text: Hey, Tim.  Merry Christmas.

speaker: Tim
text: Hey Bill, same to you.  Glad you could make it.

speaker: Bill
text: Well, I wouldn't miss this.  Hey, how's that turkey platter? Good as last year's?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm not sure this isn't last year's.  Listen, I'm done here, why don't you go ahead and take this seat?

speaker: Bill
text: Jeez, thanks pal.

speaker: Frasier
text: You bet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, excuse me miss, something rather embarrassing has just happened.  I seem to have lost my wallet.

speaker: Waitress
text: You mean you can't pay!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, I can pay, I can pay, I must have just left it at the office.

speaker: Waitress
text: Uh-huh.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I can just go back there and get it.

speaker: Waitress
text: Mmm.

speaker: Tim
text: Hey, Lou.  It's all right.  This one's on me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no-no-no.  You don't understand.  You see, I...

speaker: Tim
text: It's okay, buddy, we've all been there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but you see, I really did misplace my wallet.

speaker: Tim
text: I know you did, and Bill here misplaced his Wall Street portfolio. Here Bill, help me out. [_starts a whip round_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, you don't...

speaker: Tim
text: Hey, everybody!  People.  Come on, let's help the poor man get a nice Christmas dinner.  Even pennies.  It doesn't matter.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, please, you don't understand.  I make a very decent living.  I really do.  This is not necessary.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I must say I've never been so touched in my life.  To think that you people would give up your money, which you can ill afford, to help out a fellow human being.  I'm just so embarrassed.

speaker: Tim
text: Don't be embarrassed.  Look at it this way: the rest of the year belongs to the rich people, with their fancy houses, [_points to Frasier's BMW_] expensive foreign cars, but Christmas?  Christmas belongs to guys like us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  Well, I never will forget this Christmas.  Thank you. Thank you all. _Frasier leaves the diner and goes to his car, but turns to see everyone in the diner waving at him.  He waves back, then waits until they turn back and ducks down beneath the sill, to crawl into his car._

speaker: Waitress
text: [_picking up something from the floor_] Hey.  Somebody lose a set of car keys?  _Frasier crawls out of his car and enters the diner again.  He begins searching the floor for his keys._

speaker: Tim
text: Hey.  We're not buying you dessert.

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  No, you see, I forgot... I forgot, ah... _He pauses for a moment, torn between preserving the moment and getting his car back.  He picks the former._

speaker: Frasier
text: To wish you a Merry Christmas!

speaker: All
text: Merry Christmas.

speaker: Tim
text: Hey, bud.  Since you're here, [_gives Frasier a quarter_] go call your old man.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  I think I will.  _He leaves, deciding to walk home.  End of Act Two._
